questions.text: A 3400-g (7-lb 8-oz) newborn is delivered at 40 weeks' gestation. Physical examination shows pale skin, blond hair, and blue irides. Her parents are from Haiti and express concern, as the newborn's appearance contrasts greatly with their own. The most likely cause of this newborn's condition is a defect in which of the following processes?

choices.text: Migration of neural crest cell derivates

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abnormal intracellular transport of melanosomes is caused by a mutation in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene, a defect classically found in patients with Chediak Higashi syndrome. The impaired transport of melanin results in partial albinism (e.g., patches of depigmented skin, white forelock), not total albinism.

B) CORRECT:

Oxidation of dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosinase is an important step in melanin synthesis. A defect in this enzyme results in oculocutaneous albinism, which usually manifests with skin findings like those described in this patient and ocular findings like blue irides, choroidal hypopigmentation, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. The severity of hypopigmentation, ranging from nearly normal skin pigmentation to an almost complete absence of melanin, depends primarily on the amount of functional tyrosinase; the number of melanocytes is not altered. The deficiency of melanin can result in photosensitivity and sunburns and is, therefore, associated with an increased risk of skin cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Glycosylation of procollagen, which is a crucial step in the synthesis of collagen, is impaired in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta because of a mutation in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene. Affected individuals present with blue sclerae, not blue irides, and hypopigmentation is not typical of osteogenesis imperfecta.

D) INCORRECT:

Defective transfer of melanosomes to keratinocytes appears to be the underlying pathology in patients with postinflammatory hypopigmentation. This is an acquired disease, normally due to contact irritants or inflammatory processes, and manifests with hypomelanotic macules or patches of varying shape. This patient has a congenital condition with diffuse hypopigmentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective migration of neural crest derivatives, namely melanoblasts, during embryonic development is the underlying cause of piebaldism, which is characterized by scattered hypopigmented macules, a white forelock, and a triangular depigmented patch on the forehead. Uniform hypopigmentation and blue irides, as seen in this patient, are inconsistent with this disorder.
questions.hint: The newborn's uniform lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes suggests albinism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, nausea, headache, and confusion. Three weeks ago, he had an episode of a sore throat, diarrhea, and generalized lymphadenopathy. He is sexually active with a new partner that he met 2 months ago and they use condoms inconsistently. He appears ill. Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. Further evaluation shows infection with an enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus. The cells most likely affected in this patient’s current condition are analogous to which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ependymal cells are glial cells that line the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. They are covered in microvilli, which assist in CSF absorption. Microglial cells (not ependymal cells) are macrophages of the CNS that are similar to the immune cells targeted by HIV.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoblasts promote the development of new bone matrix during bone remodeling processes. Osteoclasts (not osteoblasts) are macrophages found in bone tissue that are similar to the immune cells targeted by HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasma cells are differentiated B lymphocytes that secrete immunoglobulins. HIV has marked tropism for certain immune cells (primarily T helper cells and macrophages). However, these cells are not analogous to plasma cells.

D) INCORRECT:

In response to allergen exposure, IgE antibodies can trigger degranulation of mast cells, which causes histamine secretion, inflammation, and allergic symptoms. Histiocytes (not mast cells) are macrophages found in connective tissue that are similar to the immune cells targeted by HIV.

E) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells are a type of glial cell that myelinates the axons of peripheral motor and sensory neurons. Resident macrophages of the peripheral nervous systems (not Schwann cells) are similar to the immune cells targeted by HIV.

F) CORRECT:

HIV mainly targets cells that express the cell surface receptor CD4 and coreceptors CCR5 or CXCR4 (i.e., macrophages and T-helper cells). Langerhans cells are bone marrow-derived dendritic cells located in the epidermis (also referred to as macrophages of the skin and mucosa) and are analogous to microglial cells, a type of tissue macrophage located in the CNS and most likely affected in a patient with HIV meningoencephalitis. HIV can infect Langerhans cells directly. The virus then migrates to lymph nodes, where it is transmitted to T-helper cells. Other types of tissue macrophages include osteoclasts, Kupffer cells, histiocytes, and alveolar macrophages.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation should raise suspicion for meningoencephalitis (fever, nausea, headache, confusion, nuchal rigidity) in the setting of acute HIV infection (enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus). The cells most likely affected in this patient are microglial cells.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a skin lesion on his right arm. The lesion first appeared 3 months ago and has since been slowly enlarging. Physical examination shows a 1.5-centimeter, faintly erythematous, raised lesion with irregular borders on the dorsum of the right forearm. A biopsy specimen is obtained. If present, which of the following histopathological features would be most consistent with carcinoma in situ?

choices.text: Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum
Irreversible nuclear changes in the stratum basale
Full-thickness basal to apical cell polarity
Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum
High mitotic activity in the stratum granulosum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

1. Normal squamous epithelium (N; green overlay): normal nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, intact cell polarity (epithelial cells have distinct lateral, apical, and basal membrane domains)

2. Mild dysplasia (1; yellow overlay): mild pleomorphism (loss of uniformity in cell size and shape), mild chromatin abnormalities (hyperchromatic), koilocytes (cells with perinuclear halos), dysplasia confined to the basal third of the epithelium

3. Moderate dysplasia (2; blue overlay): loss of cell polarity, moderate nuclear pleomorphism, moderate nuclear chromatin abnormalities, increased normal and abnormal mitosis, dysplasia confined to the basal two-thirds of the epithelium

4. Severe dysplasia (3; red overlay): irreversible high-grade dysplasia, irregular epithelial stratification, involves the entire thickness of the epithelium, clear demarcated basement membrane (no invasion)

Koilocytes in dysplastic cervical epithelium indicate an underlying persistent HPV infection as the cause of dysplasia.

B) CORRECT:

Formation of neoplasia starts with low-grade dysplasia, a reversible disordered growth of epithelium characterized by abnormally frequent mitotic figures, loss of cell orientation and uniformity, and nuclear changes. Carcinoma in situ is usually an irreversible severe (i.e., high-grade) dysplasia involving the entire thickness of the epithelium without basement membrane penetration.

C) INCORRECT:

A basal to apical cell polarity is a physiological feature of epithelial cells or epithelial cell layers, which line the body's surfaces and separate internal cavities from the outside environment. Loss of this polarity, however, is a sign of dysplasia, which may eventually lead to carcinoma in situ.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.

E) INCORRECT:

High mitotic activity in the stratum granulosum would be a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.
questions.hint: Neoplasia progresses along a predictable course from normal cellular morphology to the reversible changes of dysplasia and then to carcinoma in situ.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased sweating for the past 6 months. She experiences severe sweating that is triggered by stressful situations and speaking in public. She is failing one of her university classes because of her avoidance of public speaking. She has not had any fevers, chills, weight loss, or night sweats. Her temperature is 36.6°C (98°F). Physical examination shows moist skin in the axillae and on the palms, soles, and face. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pilocarpine is a direct parasympathomimetic (direct agonist) that binds directly to muscarinic ACh receptors, which in turn increases the secretion of sweat. Pilocarpine would worsen this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin stimulates uterine contractions and milk expression. It does not play a role in sweat gland secretion and would have no effect on this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine is an indirect parasympathomimetic (indirect agonist) that decreases the breakdown of ACh, which in turn increases the secretion of sweat. Physostigmine would worsen this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic agent that mainly affects α-1 adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction, nasal decongestion, and mydriasis. It does not play a role in sweat gland secretion and would have no effect on this patient's condition.

E) CORRECT:

Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent used to treat hyperhidrosis. This drug blocks ACh at muscarinic receptors, which temporarily reduces sweat production. As with any anticholinergic drug, careful dosing is required to avoid adverse effects of excessive ACh inhibition (e.g., flushed skin, cycloplegia, dry mouth, constipation).

Botulinum toxin, which also inhibits ACh release, can be used to treat focal hyperhidrosis (e.g., hyperhidrosis limited to the axillae).
questions.hint: Sweating is an autonomic reflex primarily mediated by acetylcholine receptors of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of blue staining of her clothes when she exercises. She noticed that the stains are most prominent on her underwear and under her arms. She works as a professional ballet dancer and trains at least 15 hours per week. Her menstrual cycles occur at regular 28-day intervals. Physical examination shows black-blue discoloration of the skin in the axillae, areolae, and perineum. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A biopsy of the skin obtained from the axilla shows lipofuscin granules within coiled secretory glands in the lower dermis; the secretory ducts of these glands empty into the infundibulum of hair follicles. Which of the following terms best describes the glands seen on this patient's biopsy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The term autocrine refers to a form of molecular signaling in which a cell produces chemical messengers that subsequently act on that same cell. The term is not used to describe exocrine glands such as sweat glands, which are the glands seen in this patient's biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

The cells of holocrine glands release content via lysis of the cell itself. Examples of holocrine glands are the sebaceous glands, Meibomian glands, and the glands of Zeis. Sebaceous glands are located in the dermis of the axillae, perineum, and areolae, and the secretory ducts of sebaceous glands empty into the infundibulum of hair follicles, as seen on this patient's biopsy. However, sebaceous glands are lobular or acinar in shape rather than coiled; the coiled glands in this patient are sweat glands, which are not holocrine glands.

C) INCORRECT:

Endocrine glands are not involved in the secretion of sweat but rather of substances (e.g., hormones) into the bloodstream or interstitial fluid. Examples of endocrine glands include the thyroid gland, adrenal glands, and the pituitary gland. Sweat is secreted by exocrine glands.

D) INCORRECT:

The term paracrine refers to a form of molecular signaling in which a cell produces a chemical messenger (e.g., hormones, cytokines) that exerts effects on local cells in direct contact with the messenger. The term is not used to describe exocrine glands such as sweat glands, which are the glands seen in this patient's biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Eccrine sweat glands, which can be affected in eccrine chromhidrosis, are present in the dermis and are coiled in shape, which is consistent with this patient's biopsy findings. However, these sweat glands are primarily located on the palms and soles rather than the axillae, perineum, and areolae. Moreover, the secretory ducts of eccrine sweat glands open directly onto the surface of the skin rather than the infundibulum of hair follicles. This patient has a different form of chromhidrosis.

F) CORRECT:

Blue stains on clothes after exercise and black-blue discoloration of the skin suggest chromhidrosis. The location of the discolored skin and the skin biopsy, which shows lipofuscin granules within secretory glands that drain into the infundibulum of hair follicles, reflect the fact that chromhidrosis most commonly affects the apocrine glands. Chromhidrosis is characterized by the production of colored sweat and typically manifests after puberty, when the development of apocrine glands is complete. It is caused by the secretion of lipofuscin granules, with the color of the sweat depending on the grade of oxidation of lipofuscin. Other examples of apocrine glands are the mammary glands, ceruminous glands, and Moll glands.
questions.hint: These glands, which are coiled in shape and located in the dermis, are sweat glands.

questions.text: A 28-year-old African American woman delivers her first child at 39 weeks' gestation. On examination, the newborn's skin and hair have a milky white color, and his eyes are light blue with a slight reddish hue. A skin biopsy shows a normal number of epidermal and follicular melanocytes. The physician advises the parents that the child will need a comprehensive eye examination and genetic testing to establish the suspected diagnosis. A defect in which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase is responsible for classic phenylketonuria (PKU), a disorder characterized by phenylalanine accumulation and tyrosine deficiency. If untreated, patients with PKU develop generalized hypopigmentation, as seen here, because tyrosine is a precursor of melanin and high phenylalanine levels inhibit the enzyme responsible for melanin synthesis. However, the clinical features of PKU are not seen at birth because the fetus obtains tyrosine from maternal blood, and excess phenylalanine (as well as its toxic byproducts) is removed by the placenta. The features of PKU (e.g., hypopigmentation, seizures, intellectual disability, a musty odor) typically develop during infancy following the initiation of feeding.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect in DOPA decarboxylase leads to a deficiency in dopamine, an important neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. During infancy, patients with DOPA decarboxylase deficiency present with hypotonia, athetosis, lethargy, and poor feeding, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation is not consistent with a defect in DOPA decarboxylase.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine kinase is primarily involved in signal transduction and cell proliferation. Defects in tyrosine kinase can result, e.g., in Bruton agammaglobulinemia (loss of function mutation of the BTK), chronic myeloid leukemia (gain of function mutation of BCR-ABL), or multiple endocrine neoplasia (gain of function mutation of RET). This patient's condition is caused by a defect in a different enzyme.

D) CORRECT:

Tyrosinase is a copper-containing enzyme in melanocytes that produces melanin from dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA), which is derived from tyrosine by the action of tyrosine hydroxylase or tyrosinase itself. Tyrosinase is encoded by the TYR gene on chromosome 11; a defect in this gene is responsible for oculocutaneous albinism type 1 (OCA1), which manifests as hypopigmentation of the hair, skin, and irides with a normal density of melanocytes on skin biopsy, as seen here. The neurological and physical development of infants with OCA1 is similar to that of normal infants, but they have an increased risk of skin cancer and visual abnormalities and therefore need to undergo skin and eye screenings periodically.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

E) INCORRECT:

A defect in homogentisate oxidase (alkaptonuria) leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and manifests as ochronosis, a blue-black discoloration of the skin, cartilage, tendons, and body fluids that come in contact with air (e.g., urine). The generalized hypopigmentation in this patient is not consistent with a defect in homogentisate oxidase.

F) INCORRECT:

Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT) is mainly found in the adrenal medulla and catalyzes the formation of epinephrine from norepinephrine. A deficiency of this enzyme is not the cause of this newborn's condition.
questions.hint: Dihydroxyphenalanine (DOPA), an intermediate compound in the synthesis of catecholamines, serves as one of the substrates of this enzyme. A deficiency of this enzyme will result in oculocutaneous albinism, as seen in this patient.
